column2: Street with many restaurants and boutiques.
column3: Located between the relative grunge of Venice Beach and the industrial value of Lincoln Boulevard, Abbot Kinney is full of chic shops, art galleries, and some great restaurants along Abbott KinneyThe restaurants are quite good and it is an environment near the beach. While you are there make sure to visit Venice beach there is a lot to see in that place.
This is a great long street to walk. Parking is tough, but worth it. Trendy stores. Hip people. Near Venice Beach

column2: Great stores, fabulous places to eat
column3: Parking is always a hassle but this is a fun street to window shop. Amazing restaurants. Get coffee and walk the Boulevard. Close to Venice beach and Santa Monica

This is a lovely but busy area of LA. Abbot Kinney is lined with shops, bars, salons and restaurants, it's very popular so prepare to shuffle your way up and down. But hey who's in a hurry anyway ona sunny weekend.. Also lots of cute doggies!
Very young hip vibe, felt safe walking there, not so many homeless ppl. Upmkt shops bars etc . Longish walk from Venice Beach
I love this street! So much to watch, to shop and eat! I like to visit this street whenever I am in LA. I highly recommend a stroll.

column2: Love this street - its a must visit in LA!
column3: What a great little walk of fun in LA. This spot in Venice Beach is just the coolest. Heaps of funky shops and cafes, and murals on walls and lots to see and explore. Highly recommended!
This road is lined with expensive shops - good for window shopping, and nice restaurants, all very upmarket.

We took Bus No 733 from Downtown and alighted at Venice/Abbot Kinney and walked along the northwest stretch to Brooks Ave.It was pre-9am and the Blvd was tranquil with only a few walking their pet dogs and some others on their way to work.It was grand strolling and admiring the varying streetscapes, from murals to plethora-styled buildings.We dropped into Cafe Intelligentsia for a tasty breakfast and enjoyed sitting on the outside steps in the sunshine.

column2: A victim of its own success
column3: I discovered Abbott Kinney many years ago when its main street still had a mix of thrift and vintage stores, local coffee joints and surfy bars. Frank Gehry was doing his thing in Venice, and the Eames Office was still open in nearby Rose Street. Back then, you could really feel that this place still had the authenticity that was starting to disappear from LA's beach cities. Those quirky places are gone now - replaced by high end retailers and boutiques. The bars and restaurants have been scrubbed clean for the hordes of tourists that have discovered (and killed) whatever it was that made this place unique. If I could put a roof over the main street, this may as well be a high end mall. So, my visits have become less - opting instead to go further west on Lincoln where interesting shops are starting to pop up, or to DTLA where the artistic vibe is still exciting but edgy enough to stave off the total gentrification that has become synonymous with Abbott Kinney.

We stayed near here and its not really that different from any other street in the world!! It has expensive shops and some bars/restaurants. Fri & Sat nights it is packed with food wagons and people using them. Good atmosphere on these nights altho watch out for pick pockets we were told. Really nothing special during the daytime though!
This is a great strip to hit up all the trendy shops and snack places while hoping on a mobile bird scooter and buzzing your way over to Venice and Santa Monica beach fronts.

column2: Great off the beaten path find
column3: Great area of Venice. Avoid the chain stores and head to this boutique area for good shopping, great food and good people watching. We have loved in the LA area for 20 years and never been here. It’s worth the drop in and worth a day of your time. Bring your appetite great places to stop and have a drinkWhether that be coffee or spirits!

The funk has pretty much dissipated and fancy name brands and brands with lots of negative space and expensive items line this street. Fun to walk down, people watch and check out some of the shops, but, at the end of the day, it’s really silly expensive catering more to money than creativity. Some good restaurants, for sure. A pity though it’s not more real.

column2: Go on your own mural tour
column3: My friend and I spent about an hour walking up and down the street, looking at the shops and murals. As someone who loves street art, it was fun to see all the different murals, and they change all the time too so you'll see new ones any time you go! Definitely worth a stroll.
Well worth a detour away from the beach. Beautiful boutique shops & independent eateries. Spent a good 1.5 hours here with all entertained.

Abbot Kinney is a trendy road where you can find trendy every things, food, clothes, art etc. It used to be more artsy but is progressively getting "cooler". A fun place to hang out in Venice and lots of good options for food and shopping.

This is a nice place to visit if you are in the area. Small trendy boutiques, coffee shops and fancy restaurants plus the local residents give a nice vibe. The Erewhon Grocery store at one end has superb organic produce and excellent prepared foods, at a price.You can probably spend an hour here, longer if eating or drinking.Be aware if you go a few blocks away you expose yourself to LA’s seamier side, especially as you approach the boardwalk.

This small shopping street in Venice has become a dirty, scummy neighborhood with trendy juice bars and a few good stores. The area isn’t welcoming to visitors and the traffic can be awful.The parking is a nightmare and it’s hard to justify high end retail and food with the area’s robust and sometimes scary homeless population.This street needs a good nightly pressure washing and some tlc.

column2: A trendy street for eating and shopping in Venice
column3: This is one of the nicest shopping streets in LA, with lots of small stores/boutiques as well as wonderful restaurants such as Gjelina (reservations essential) and The Butcher’s Daughter (veggie). At weekends, be prepared for a long line outside Salt and Straw, the delicious ice cream store. And Lemonade has delicious salads and different fresh lemonades.Abbot Kinney Boulevard is not far from Venice Beach but feels like a world away.

column2: So many fun shops and great restaurants
column3: My friend turned me on to Abbot Kinney Blvd about 5 years ago and I've returned several times since. It has fun boutique stores, great restaurants, and a cool vibe. Definitely worth a stroll when you're near Venice Beach.
always a fun day to walk along AB and stop in the various shops and then stop and have a drink or eat lunch/dinner...lots of choices and quite bohemenian!
Abbot Kinney has become a very popular street for cool and trendy shops. It has lots to offer for locals and tourists alike.
In addition to strolling the beach scene at Venice, walk along Abbot Kinney Boulevard for the cool shops and restaurants, murals and street art. This use to be a canal!

column2: Dont Miss it if You are in Vennice
column3: Cool Shopping Street!!! Lots of shops and restaurant options! Great sunny afternoon activity! It is a good walk from Vennice Beach
Very stylish, restaurants and shops with a quirky feel.. a nice walk.. nb. Doesnt really start until north of Venice blvd..
This place has a fantastic vibe, the Pizza there is great and you sometimes bump into celebrities , I bumped into Toby Meguire :)

column2: A slice of Santa Monica in Venice
column3: Situated between the relative grunge of Venice beach and the industrial value of Lincoln Boulevard, Abbot Kinney is instead filled with fancy shops, fancy cafes and fancy people (I saw two separate photoshoots in progress). Might be good for visitors who want to shop for something other than souvenirs and pot.
Lots of restaurants, galleries, fun stores. It is a good place to stroll on a lovely SoCal day take in the sights and have something to eat. Can really get mobbed on weekends.

column2: Trendy place not to be missed on your trip to Venice
column3: There are art galleries and some great restaurants along Abbott Kinney and the parking is not that difficult to find. Most of the restaurants are quite good and it is an easy atmosphere near the beach. While you are there be sure to go to Venice Beach

column2: Kings Rd Chelsea in the sixties.
column3: On weekends it is worth visiting to see the inhabitants and visitors. Anything goes. We were not surprised to see a film crew operating. Quieter on weekdays but easier to eat and shop then. A variety of bars, cafes and Ice cream parlours. Great fun but not so much for infants.An essential part of the LA experience, near Venice and Santa Monica.
We came here for a bit of last minute shopping the place was lovely trendy and full of different restaurants and a great ice cream parlour .

If you are in Venice Beach the first Friday of the month go to Abbot Kinney Blvd for a truly awesome California food experience. You can pick from 20-30 food trucks which congregate between 6-10pm. Tourists don't know about this so it is very local and authentic. The food varies from Greek, Thai, BBQ, Burgers to anything you can think of. Parking is impossible to take an Uber or park and take an electric scooter over.

column2: This is a Hip Location for Shopping and Food
column3: This area has some great shops to explore for clothes, art and adorable consumer goods. There are plenty of good eating spots to recharge your battery and lots of good people watching. I enjoy sitting eating an ice cream cone watching the world go by.

If you're into shopping, like boutiques vs big box stores, are looking for unique items at a price point that's in between department stores and designer prices - then this street is for you! Great for restaurants, clothing, and some jewelry. Come on the weekend if possible, as there are a lot of pop-up sellers that turn up that you don't see during the week (yes, I loved this area so much I came back multiple times).

Despite coming to LA and specifically Venice so many times over the years, this Boulevard had escaped me Have stuck to the beach area and not ventured into these parts and now wondering why.It's a great shopping street without the bling and superficality of Rodeo Street and also has a more realistic and "normal" style of shops. A good range of cafes and restaurants as well.

Really Cool Shopping Street!!! Lots of eclectic shops AND restaurant options! Parking can be a challenge but has always been worth it. Great sunny afternoon activity! Also fun to tie it in with a local Farmers Market or Flea Market event!

On Saturday afternoon there was an interesting Maker’s Market at one end of the drag. As with all this type of bazaar, the items ranged from terrific to terrible and back again. Still with no entry fee it’s worth a gander. The strip is a wide variety of shops and restaurants, nothing too too high end or too tacky. Lots of people watching. Close to Venice Beach so after an hour or so meandering up and down Abbot Kinney, we left to watch the skateboarders in the skate park on the beach. Lots to see and do there, too.

column2: Quirky street for a slow stroll to take in the shops and the atmosphere
column3: Some amazing shops, almost all seem to be non-chain independent stores, selling all sorts and some great looking bars, cafes and ice cream parlours - obviously the best having queues outside, even in March!There are also plenty of murals painted on walls and one of girl chopped out of wall plaster. Fantastic!

If you're visiting L.A., I recommend you set aside some time to walk up and down Abbot Kinney. Parking is a bit difficult, but have patience and hopefully you'll luck out. There are restaurants, boutiques, Blue Star Donuts, Tom's (nice espresso bar inside Tom's), Marine Layer (clothing) to give you an idea of what's there. And the Venice canals aren't too far away. They are worth a stroll through to see the canals and funky architecture of houses along the canal.
very different and unique strip that is off the beaten path but so cool at all the same time one the areas that a must in la

We loved strolling the boulevard and going in and out of the shops and stores here. Lots of great places to eat, lots of people watching. We found some great things in the stores and had a great time!
Nice place for shoppers and if you time. As a man it was not always my kind of shops. Looking for something special you will find it here. Expensive.

column2: A Great Collection of Restaurants and Boutiques
column3: Love the vibe in this part of LA! A great selection of great boutiques and organic and vegetarian restaurants. Artsy and fun!
Nice boulevard to stroll along but I personally think it's overrated as the best shopping boulevard but it does have several nice restaurants, coffewhops and is therefor worthwhile to visit
If you want some shops that are out of the norm stop here. Unique and fun shops. Pricey but easy to get around.
Great vibe - incredible restaurants ( Plant Food and Wine, Butcher's Daughter, Gjelina and MANY more!). Many interesting, unique and beautiful stores.

column2: Hip street with great eateries and boutiques
column3: Great street ( several blocks) full of shops and restaurants. Best thing is that it’s not the shops you usually see in malls and other shopping areas. The not so good things is that it is very expensive so mainly window shopping

column2: A great street to stroll, shop and eat
column3: This is my favorite street to shop on when in los angeles. There are some unique stores and some excellent restaurants.

column2: must visit in Venice - cool street
column3: I have actually heard a lot about Abbot Kinney (mainly from celebrities). So I had very high expectations and that's why I didn't give 5 stars. It's a very cool/trendy place. I had a fun time eating a walking up and down the street for a few hours.I highly recommend visiting if you're in the area. Great place to just take a stroll and grab a healthy smoothie or craft coffee, plus more.

column2: Hotspot to see and to be seen
column3: Beautiful people, cute little stores, very charming bars give all the trendy climate of this street.Walk around and try a beer or wine and watch out, cause you might bump into a star any minute.

every first friday of every month there are a hundred food trucks offering all there different specialties, there is a variety of shops if you get there earlier and if you don't want food trucks there are plenty of good restaurants
Great lively little street filled with adorable little shops and great restaurants all unique and funky as well. I love the pizza at gejlena and the delicious pasta at Felix and....

column2: great stretch of shops out of the mainstream
column3: Stumbled across this stretch of lovely boutique shops whilst hunting down my favourite American watch shop, Shinola. Well worth a stroll and a peek inside some different and interesting fashion stores and cafes

We had to stop by here to see what the interest was in this area. It was well worth the stop. We parked along a side street and walked the Boulevard window shopping and people watching. We did stop at one location to purchase ice cream to take with us to enjoy the stores.

Walking city streets isn't typically a California preoccupation, but Abbot Kinney is the closest to an urban scene to this East Coaster. Crowded sidewalks with quirky, high priced stores and a see and be seen type vibe. It includes a legal marijuana store! Alot of fun!
Love these quaint shops and the ambiance of the neighborhood! Thank you Abbot Kinney for providing such a diverse, safe place to shop/window shop

column2: Interesting slice of urban living in Venice
column3: We like to stroll on the street, to view the various stores and restaurants and to eat in our favorite one. Going in mid day in mid week helped.
Fantastic restaurants, original shops, great coffee! It's popular place to go, the new 'spot' to see and be seen in LA by the beach.
Fun area higher end shops and resturants . We ate at the butchers daughter it was excellent a nice change from the beach area the donut shop was also very good
A lot of interesting shops, not just the same old same old chains high or low, with a variety of price points, and lots of food options...
A great place to dine, shop or stroll. It's a great place to meet friends or to find a name brand flagship store or a one of a kind funky shop.

column2: This close to Venice Beach Blvd has everything within walking distance
column3: The vibe is excellent, many stores to chose from, and more important many places to eat - pizza places, vegan restaurantes, cafes, ice cream parlor, even a swap meat on Sundays. it is worth a visit. I've been there many times, you can walk to Venice Beach and see Muscle Beach.
When in LA, we always take a walk on Abbot Kinney, to have a feel of the latest trends, not just in California, but also in the rest of the world. And if we can get in, we have dinner at Gjelina.

column2: A street full of great shops and restaurants
column3: This street is known for gourmet, specialty restaurants as well as a few VERY GOOD pizza places. Boutique clothing stores are between the eateries and parking is actually on the street behind Abbot Kinney.

We were there for the Abbot Kinney Festival and the street was blocked off and lined with stalls and food and drinks. We had a great time and explored the area. A variety of shops and restaraunts and to our amazement - places to buy weed ;)

The many venues and businesses in the old buildings along AK are pretty neat. Vendors, shop owners and eating spots abound and all visited had good, fun attitudes. made two trips to the area while in town recently
enjoy your vacation by booking a place near here walk 5 min to great shopping, and food choices, must go to salt straw

Well dressed, good looking, well heeled tourists, mostly. More Chic than Beach vibe. Fun place to walk around before dining. TOMS coffee shop, plus a few, loud noisy bars. Gift shops. Clothing Boutiques for Sitcom TV Stars. There's also a MedMen on this street.

Everybody there is just amazing. I bought my first (but not last) John Fluevog shoes there :D The people at the store were so loving and frendly. The same thing in all the stores. Friendly and lovely people all around.

My favorite place in Venice! It is a very colorful street with unique graffitis! The store are mostly boutique shops where you can buy some nice stuff! There is a wide variety of restaurants, coffee shops and ice cream shop.

column2: Unique but Needs Variety... And Restrooms!
