The rustic hipster look is a bit overdone, and there needs to be public restrooms i all the shopkeepers are going to be wary of the public using theirs. Otherwise, it's a nice way to spend an hour or two in L.A.
This is very London/SoHo ish.I recommend it.Mainly the modern version of YUPPIES but lots of quaint shops and good food

column2: Can't see what the hype is about
column3: Walked this road one night looking for a friendly bar to sit in. Only found pretentious places. I do not see what the hype is about and was also very quiet.

column2: Nice part of town, Tourist Destination and Expensive
column3: We enjoyed the shops and restaurants along Abbott Kinney but we never actually bought anything or ate anything but an ice cream. It's a very hipster area and worth seeing but it is very expensive.
If you're on Abbott Kinney, make sure you stop at Blue Star donuts!! It's the only place I've actually gone into.

column2: Great shopping and restaurants with colorful art murals around
column3: I went shopping here most stores are high end and expensive but I did find a store here that had sales and was very inexpensive. Make sure you were good walking shoes if you go on this long busy street to shop. I had to buy a pair of sneakers at adidas store here because my feet were hurting so bad. This street is very colorful and full of art murals on the corners. Lots of stores to shop at and places to eat. There is a great ice cream place here. I recommend coming here just to see this street and take a walk.

column2: Nice Shops And Places To Eat
column3: A great place for shopping and eats.Here, you will find hip, chick, bizarre and just about everything when it comes to clothes.It's a great shopping experience.Take your time and have a coffee.Plenty of places to relax and eat.Enjoy.George Vreeland Hill
Great shopping from Alternative to Ruti to Rag&Bone. Great coffee shops, restaurants and jewelry stores. Love the leather store, Will. Great place to look for a gift.

Cute street with adorable shops, boutique clothing stores and eateries. Not in the BEST area which gives it 4 Stars. We took an electric scooter here and it was a little sketchy. Uber and it’s a bit safer.

column2: Fun People Watching & Places but VERY Crowded
column3: This is a fun part of the greater Los Angeles area to visit. Huge selection of eclectic shops and places to eat from the cheapest eats to the highest gourmet. Great stores, beautiful people and something for everyone and every budget. Huge downside for me, and the thing that keeps from there most of the time is the crowd - both on the sidewalk and driving. I get there from time to time but generally the traffic is too much for me. However, it is a fun place!

Very cool upscale shops a fun place to walk and discover if you have the time and money. It has gotten more commercialized and a lot of the cool artist can no longer afford the area but it still has a vibe selling the socal dream
We enjoyed walking this trendy street popping into the mostly independent shops. It’s a nice break from the beach with lots of places to eat and drink
had such a fun day strolling through, had amazing food, ice cream, and shopped at the cutest places. highly recommend spending an afternoon or morning there.

column2: Great place to so some fun shopping.
column3: Just love Abbot Kinney to stroll along the boulevard and windoshop and eat a great meal at the many wonderful restaurants.

Come for amazing food such as Gjelina and stay for the high end boho chic shopping. You can buy jewelry with healing stone properties, fizzy iced matcha teas, and get a great facial at Alexandra Wagner. Can't go wrong spending an afternoon or evening here, but it will not be inexpensive.

What a great way to spend a sunny day in LA! Bike or walk it. Take your time. Shop, eat, check out the artwork. And go slow!It's an EZ ride and wonderfully connects Venice and Santa Monica, two awesome towns to spend 2-3 days at in LA!

column2: Fun place to walk and shop
column3: Located close to Venice Beach which is as funky as it gets this area is sort of upscale with lots of shops, local and national names, restaurants, bars, ice crean wine shops - plenty of choices for everyone or just a nice walk.

A wonderful "Main Street" for strolling, people watching, shopping and dining in LA. There are some fantastic restaurants along this strip along with nice home design stores like Huset and upscale retailers like John Fluevog, Rag & Bone and Alexis Bittar. Salt had a nice selection of gifts, jewelry and kid stuff.Lots of cafes and specialty food stops like Blue Star Donuts and Salt & Straw for ice cream. Abbot Kinney gave us a respite from driving and an opportunity to get out of the car and stretch our legs. Fun street art all along the avenue for those seeking out visual treats.

column2: A Must For Local / Artsy California Vibe
column3: LOVE Abbot Kinney for the shopping and local vibe. Last year, we happened to visit during their annual street fest - Abbot Kinney Festival, which I highly suggest! So many great vendors and set-up shops on top of the great businesses already there.
got to keep your eyes on the road though, looks of things to look at but people cross all over the place

This street is very hip and cool, lots of small designer stores and cafes. We loved walking down and seeing all the graffiti on the sides of the shops.This is very much an expensive designer boutique-y street and we were most definitely only window shopping. We did however stop for a drink in the original Tom's store which has a café and really cute outdoor seating area.This street is not far from Venice beach and worth a look if you have any interest in street art or finding a unique souvenir.
It is very nice to walk along this street. Nice mix of shopping and places to get some food. Good for whole family and dog too.

We really thought that this place was going to be buzzing , but it was drab and boring ,and really not worth our time . It sounds so exciting from all the reviews and travel blogs . All the places to eat were packed and the shops were overpriced . This really is nota place where we will visit again .

This is a great stretch to walk down when in the Venice beach area. There is an eclectic mix of restaurants and shops that are more unique than the average chain store. It is also unbelievably expensive so it’s fun to look around, maybe not to buy things unless you have a deep wallet. There are really incredible murals all over the street as well in alleys coming off of Abbot Kinney that I really enjoyed seeing. There is also really great people watching. Everyone is impeccably dressed in a very artistic and unique, but clearly curated way. I had a great time walking up and down Abbot Kinney with my friends.
Not like many other parts of LA. Very many interesting shops and restaurants. A bit pricy but good place to visit.

column2: Oh no. Time’s up on Abbot Kinney
column3: It was fun while it lasted but now Abbot Kinney Blvd is awash with the sort of people who wouldn’t have stepped foot in it just a few years ago.I’m sure they’re all lovely but it’s transformation has been sudden to dilettante visitor like me.Gone are the quirky and specialist thrift shops, the 1970s surf-boarders who tell a good yarn and the gloriously edgy cafes.Now it’s all about big money and the whole character has changed. For the worse. It reminded me of Bond St in London. Urgh.Mercifully there’s always Silver Lake which shows that LA can still do attitude.
i think this place was designs with instagram in mind. a great place to shop and eat if you are looking at "artisanal" brands and food.

Spent a day wandering up and down Abbot Kinney with my teenager. The sales people in every store were attentive and friendly. Lots of great shops and funky restaurants. Velvet, Sweaty Betty, Margaret O'Leary just to name a few great shops. Highly recommend!

Abbot Kinney is meant to be one of the most hip streets in LA. In actual fact it’s a street full of would be hipsters and overrated cafes and restaurants.Several of the coffee shops eg Industry have wanky coffee offerings where coffee is individually blended.Novelty Alley!!

column2: Wish we had longer to explore
column3: Great place to spend the day. From the cute shops to amazing restaurants. This is the place to experience Venice in all it's glory.
This was a very cool area with quaint shops and great food. All places had their own character, and it was very clean.

column2: Just an overpriced outdoor mall now
column3: OK, got to be honest, years ago Abbot Kinney was unique with lots of oddball stores, interesting restaurants and other quirks. Then it was crowed one of the "top shopping streets" in the world, rents skyrocketed and all those places got pushed out. Today, some of the quaint beach-town architecture remains, but virtually all the stores occupying those buildings are owned by major global brands that can afford to pay ridiculous rents just to have a "presence." The traffic along the street has also gotten out of control.So, basically at this point it's mostly an expensive outdoor mall for high-priced brands. If that's your thing, you'll enjoy it. Otherwise, maybe you'll like laughing at the prices. Otherwise, it's harder and harder to find anything really special about what's here.If you look carefully, you can still see a handful of house/store fronts that exhibit the artistic quirkyness that it interesting before most of it was redesigned by corporate marketing departments. If you want to find the places where the current "hip" people are shopping, it isn't here anymore. Try Echo Park or Silverlake, maybe Eagle Rock.

It doesn’t get any hipper than Abbot Kinney on A weekend afternoon The trendiest LA stores and outfits found here. This means great window (or actual) shopping and people watching. The weather is usually perfect and the coffee shops and eateries memorable.

column2: Relaxed California Vibe with Great Shopping
column3: If you have an afternoon open, and your interested in shopping or even just window browsing, this is a great street for you.There are so many wonderful and unique boutiques and eateries.The vibe is very laid back and exactly California Cool.Locals and tourists ride bikes and scooters.The stretch is not that long, so take your time. Soak in the artsy vibe.It’s not a far drive from downtown LA, so it’s easy to squeeze in one afternoon.If you’re up to more walking, head down to the beach and put your feet in the sand.

Great street filled with boutiques and cool restaurants and cafes. Not cheap, it's the posh part of Venice with some overpriced restaurants and some good ones. Very artsy, lot of graffitis on side streets.
You have amazing bars, amazing restaurants and beautiful stores. This street is perfect to have a fun afternoon. Perfect in combination with Venice Beach

column2: First Fridays - a food experience like no other
column3: If you really want to experience LA, visit Abbot Kinney for dinner the first Friday of the month. There, food truck after food truck gathers to serve you tastes from around the world - and some tastes only found in LA. From lobster rolls and philly cheesesteaks to sushiritos and fusion tacos, every bite will be an experience. Bring a friend so you can split some meals - you'll want to try about 15 different courses. Most trucks take credit cards, but I always bring some cash in case.There are also great shops and restaurants during the day, and some art studios that I always end up finding my way into. The canals are close by, and the area is a little more local than the beach. If you can't make it on the first Friday of the month, but still need dinner, I recommend Abbot Pizza Co. for a great slice instead.

column2: wish this location could be dropped on the oceanfront in Venice
column3: Hipster central with lots of nice restaurants and non-chain stores to shop at . My family really enjoyed it

column2: Stop here on your way to Venice Beach
column3: This is an interesting shopping street with some of the more special eating establishments on the west side. Get coffee from one of the outstanding vendors, shop in one-of-a-kind stores and just stroll.

column2: always something new to see here
column3: as an alternative to roberston or melrose, come here for the fashion and to see and be seenusually can get street parking and hangout at toms for the shoes and coffee
I have found this boulevard not very interesting.I was expecting much more people walking around and some more shops and boutiques.

Abbot Kinney is full of trendy shops, cafes and restaurants. I love going down there on a weekday and just strolling around, grabbing a bite and then going into my favorite spiritual bookstore, Mystic Journey. You can't go wrong on Abbot Kinney.

A Abbott Kinney Boulevard é uma daquelas ruas descoladas pelas quais é ótimo passear. Lá se encontra de tudo, desde bons restaurantes (falaremos mais adiante) a lojas exclusivas e de produtos com excelente bom gosto! Tenho certeza que muitos de vocês vão se sentir muito bem passeando pelas calçadas dessa rua! Recomendo, é muito!The Abbott Kinney Boulevard is one of those funky streets that's great for a stroll. There you will find everything from good restaurants (we will talk later) to exclusive shops and products with excellent taste! I'm sure many of you will feel great walking down the sidewalks of this street! Highly recommend it!

column2: Great district of shops and restaurants!
column3: Abbot Kinney Blvd is a great district of shops and restaurants! Fantastic people watching as well. They also have one night a month of food trucks.

This is a high street not far from Venice Beach or Santa Monica and has heaps of great dining options and the cutest shops that offer different/ locally made stuff. Loads of street art too that was world class
This street has many choices of restaurants and shops, mostly clothing and furnishings. It is very walkable and often the location of street festivals. It has a relaxed hip vibe.

column2: Cool street with a chilled vibe
column3: Abbott Kinney has some fantastic restaurants and boutiques.It leans to the chic and new age type of vibe.I would definitely recommend this street for 20-30 year olds. Unfortunately for us we had our kids and most of the bars and restaurants did not appear kid friendly. Such a lovely street though.

If you want to visit unusual quirky shops, bars & eateries then Abbot Kinney Blvd is a must! we had great time wandering around looking in all the fantastic shops for some unusual things to buy.Well worth a visit.

I must say, after living in LA for many years, this place has changed dramatically. It's a really nice area located next to big tech companies such as Google, Snapchat, etc. The vibe is great all day. It's really energetic, young crowd and it's nice to walk and window shop. This place is like Bushwick, BK by the beach if you're into that.

column2: The neatest vibe & people in the nation
column3: This strip makes you want to freeze time and just stay in the moment. From young men skating down the street with their bulldog at their side, to watching stars film pieces for a movie, to the food and shops, this is a must when your in Cali. The people watching and vibe here is unlike any other, it makes it extremely hard to go home. Check it out for yourself! :)

Abbot Kinney is a hip, fun and upmarket part of Venice. There are beautiful clothes and craft stores as well as organic takeouts and high end vegan restaurants.We found Fala Bar (A healthy Vegan subway-style casual dining spot), the Butcher's Daughter, offering vegan and vegetarian cuisine as well as a Vegan ice cream van randomly parked on the Boulevard.The ambiance of the Boulevard is chilled out and vibrant and you can find everything you need in one spot. The Boulevard is named after tobacco pioneer Abbot Kinney who wanted to bring Italy's Venice to California. Be sure to check out the Venice canal way that he built during the renovation in the 1930s.

column2: Actually walkable even though it is in California
column3: A good example of beautiful urban renewal,Abbot Kinney is one of the Westside's hippest havens.Good restaurants like Gjelina and the streets new star Felix.
Creative and beautiful shops around, I spent half a day walking around. Such a cool place to see and explore before or after the beach!

On the first Friday of every month the food trucks gather along the Abbot Kinney Boulevard, it's a great way to get a cheap meal, and there are so many different cuisines to choose from, lots of trucks to choose from. It does get pretty busy, but if you are in town it's a must.

This is one of my fav’ streets in LA. If the weather’s nice, a stroll on Abbot Kinney is a perfect morning or afternoon time-passing activity. The shops are cute & unique, you have awesome street art and beautiful folks to stare as they walk or roll by. . You have Intelligentsia Coffee for superb drinks. You have Gjelina or Lemonade for great food. There’s usually parking on the small streets nearby. AND, it’s not far from the beach. Highly recommend.

column2: Get here on First Fridays of the month
column3: Abbot Kinney First Fridays is a very nice event for foodies because on the first friday of the month food trucks gather here and you can enjoy tasty meal and wonderful atmosphere. It operates between 5 and 11 PM and you can find the food trucks along the street between Venice Blwd and Westminster Awe.

column2: Best street to walk - reminds me of SoHo in NYC!
column3: Fell in love with the street. It has everything you can name it on just one street. Many options to eat. My favorite thing to do during Sundays. Worth a visit if you are in mood to look around and grab a bite. I never fail to leave without a thing from that street. Reminds me of SoHo in New York except that street have palm trees. Very California style!
Ok area, totally changed over the past 20 + years. Not for the average joe and definitely not an attraction. On the pricey side. the beach is so close I think that would be a better choice.
Great restaurants, ice cream and shopping! Its like a soho of la in some ways. slightly upscale and hipster now.

column2: A one time visit, unless you find your kind of thing there.
column3: An eclectic mix of shops and restaurants, a walk and a pop in to see local products is a good idea. I bought some candles. Most stores are one off ones and have interesting designs. Some lovely coffee shops. Worth a visit.

column2: Used to be funky, now it is hip
column3: Used to be funky, now it is hip. Always interesting to watch neighborhoods transition and change. Way back in time it was hippie haven with fascinating parties. Now it is trending toward hipsters. It has always been a fun place to hang. Only the prices are more dear today.

column2: Must see when in the area
column3: Great spot for window shopping, some good bars, craft beer and cosy places to eat. You don't end up spending too much time here I guess but it's definitely worth popping by.

I couldn't figure out what was the big deal about this place. Yes there were some original stores and items lets say but they were not one of a kind really in that sense. Quiet expensive to shop or to eat just because it local made is not enough, the quality wasn't impressive.

column2: Variety of Restaurants and Shopping to choose from
column3: Abbot Kinney Boulevard has public parking nearby, you just have to find it. Otherwise there is plenty of opportunity for valet parking.The street has a lot of shopping options and restaurants as well. The shops are more on the pricey end in my opinion, but the atmosphere is very nice.
Long street, filled with original shops and restaurants, 10 minutes from the beach.. Great coffee shops and lots of people around.
Best place to shop in LA if you are more into local shops and cute stores. Plus there is the beach right next door.

column2: Great Place for Food, Walking Around and Shopping
column3: They have the greatest Free Festival on Sept 24th. with things for the kids and a beer garden, 100s of vendors and great music. Every day there are many great places to eat and shop, people watching, people just walking around.

This is a great LA street to spend the day wandering and shopping. Loved seeing the amazing street art. Enjoyed the galleries - especially G2 Gallery, which showcases nature and wildlife photography. It also has an awesome gift shop! Plenty of places to eat and not far from the busy beach boardwalk.

column2: It has a character, great place to hang out
column3: Besides some shopping, the most fun part for me were the cafes/bars/restaurants. Some are for breakfast, some are for dinner. Great place that has a character.
I loved this street! Adored the shops and restaurants we found here. Parking is a bit difficult to find as is all of LA, take an Uber.

Spent the afternoon walking down Abbot Kinney doing window shopping and eating lunch. Lots of very interesting storefronts and unique restaurants. Walking from Santa Monica, this was a great path to take on our way to the Venice Canals, which was convenient.
This street was recommended for cute shops and restaurants. We don't really like shopping and the restaurants were pricey little organic type places, so if you like that you may like Abbot Kinney.

column2: Great food, art stores and window shopping!
column3: Can't miss hitting Abbot Kinney Blvd if you're visiting LA or hanging out on the Westside - great restaurants for any time of day, fun bars, terrific hidden gem shops, and to just go window shopping for the afternoon. Cool vibe - great neighborhood.

We spent one afternoon strolling down Abbot Kinney. Lots of moderate to high end boutiques and eateries. We were able to find metered parking in the street in the late afternoon on a Wednesday.Keep in mind that many shops close in the early evening, at least on the weekdays.Visit Tom's flagship store... Really cool vibe in the back of the shop. They sell coffee and such and have an area just to lounge. We ate at Wabi Sabi 🍣 Sushi. We got there before 6 so happy hour was still going on (lesser priced items). The restaurants on either side of Wabi Sabi are also very popular. One is a unique pizza place that we wanted to try but ran out of time on our vacation.We also had ice cream at Salt and Straw. Gluten and dairy free selections. Great ice cream.There is also a gourmet donut shop on the strip with very interesting selections... Blue Star Donuts.
Lots of quirky shops away from the Venice boardwalk. A highlight was the pet shop that we visited which the staff appeared friendly with lots of interesting pet products.
While the boardwalk can be cool, if you want real shops that sell more than t-shirts and hats then head a few blocks over. Great shops and restaurants. Nice mix of both

We love stopping here each visit to LA. Great street for people watching. Cute shops and one of a kind gifts for home etc. Be sure to come hungry too, there are some outstanding restaurants to visit while you wander. Parking can be a touch tricky on weekends so be sure to get there early.
If you like your fashion this is somewhere to visit. All bespoke. Some great restaurants and if you fancy a pizza I can't recommend Abbot Kinney Pizza enough

I am not sure what all the hype is about. There are a lot of clothing and accessories shops and a few restaurants. Maybe I am not the targeted demographic. Frankly I was expecting more. It was a nice walk. Only about six blocks and then cut over to the boardwalk.

We just spent the day trolling the strip and have to say we were blown away! There really is something for everyone here. There are some expensive shops but many places that offer very cool goods at fair prices. You have to take your time. Loads of great food choices too!!
THIS is the kind of shopping street you want to find in LA. Full of fun local boutiques. There is the TOMS flagship store as well. Great stroll. Allow about an hour or so from top to bottom.

column2: Pretentious? Yes. Necessary to Visit? Yes!
column3: Abbot Kinney is a street full of overpriced shops, really good restaurants (Gjelina), good coffee (Blue Bottle, Tom's) and great people watching. Want ice cream? Head to Salt & Straw. Need a donut fix? Blue Star has lots of exotic and unique flavors. The bar scene leaves much to be desired, but Wabi Sabi is cool. You will find typical and atypical Venice hipsters all around you, as well as the occasional celebrity. Keep your eyes peeled!

if you get to stay near Venice beach, take a bus to browse Abbot Kinney area. It is a long boulevard you can walk along many boutique like shops. There are many local shops that you don't want to miss. If you have a car, simply find a street spot, but weekend it may be challenging. Public Parking costs about 15$ per 2hrs, 20$ per day during weekend.
Lovely spot - we went there for half afternoon shopping and end up having cocktails and dinner there! Awesome shopping spot and lots of bars and restaurants around! Loved it!

I was surprised that TripAdvisor had Abbott Kinney as an "attraction." It does have very trendy upscale eateries & boutiques but it is a fairly small boulevard adjacent to Venice, Santa Monica & Culver City.A VERY NICE DAY OUT would be to park near Abbot Kinney Blvd. & Venice Blvd. and walk west to the Venice Beach Boardwalk, head north to Santa Monica's Main Street and then return to your car by Abbot Kinney - but it IS a lot of walking.

Funky to upscale independent shops. Window shop or make a purchase (or, two or three!). I especially liked Tortoise General Store and Burro. The Butcher's Daughter is a neat vegetarian/vegan restaurant there, btw.

Totally original stuff all over this shopping area. Feels like you are discovering something totally new. This is the anti-mall. Fascinating shops, original designers, amazing presentations and retail settings. Interesting food along the way. Loved it.
Great nook for shopping and dinning. In March it was pretty foggy in the afternoon and so it was pretty chilly. Needed a sweater.

column2: Great street lined with cool, independent shops
column3: It's well worth walking down this street. There are some lovely, upmarket shops and great little eateries.

column2: Kreation is a must for juice and kale wraps, shopping is all around anything and any price point <3
column3: Love the vibe here! The Burro shopping store is a must look for cards, books, jewelry and basically any cool stuff.

Why do people say it's long and needs to be broken up? It's about six blocks of shops and food. If you've been to Seattle, Portland, or any somewhat sizable city I can think of, you've seen most of these products/stores. It's a perfectly lovely street to go get a $186 pre-distressed sweatshirt (really - saw that), or what is probably a good slice of pizza, or a hand-made ice cream. I just can't figure out why it's a tourist destination. The neighborhood is lovely, the people were nice. We were staying nearby and enjoyed a couple of hours of wandering. It just wasn't remarkable enough to warrant a special trip. Unless, of course, you are from a very small town, in which case, please enjoy yourself and do not die of sticker shock.

column2: Boutique shops, restaurants and great vibe!
column3: This street reminds me of what Chestnut Street in San Francisco was like 10 or more years ago. Rents are way up here but it has not been homogenized by chain stores yet. Great selection of boutiques, unusual clothes, awesome shoe store so artistic, the best pizza place in LA, coffee house, lots of people, bicyclists, so much to see...

what a great place to while away a few hours...meandering the boutiques, eating some of the best ice cream i have tasted outside of Sicily, eating a great meal in The Butchers Daughter, picking up some of the best cards "I cared..then I didnt!' was my fave! From a an amazing organic supermarket to some of the best donuts its a great place to wander and people watch. At the top of the Blvd take a left and a ten minute walk bring you to the famous Venice Beach.

column2: Very trendy street full of cool individual stores, healthy restaurants and beautiful architecture
column3: Abbot Kinney is today what Melrose used to be, just better, cleaner and much more original. The street is full a small, individual shops, cute stores, great healthy restaurants and beautiful little houses. The crowd is very boho-chique, trendy yet down to earth, very LA. Great shopping and great people watching.

These several blocks packed with hip, funky (and expensive) shops and restaurants is a fun place to stroll. You can enjoy and afternoon away from the beach, window shopping, people watching and stopping for a coffee or ice cream.

column2: great street to spend some time
column3: we rode our bikes from Santa Monica and spent some time wandering down this street. We loved it all the great restaurants and cafes and shops made a lovely morning out. We even came back a second time to eat.

Enjoyed a beautiful afternoon in Venice with my 20-something daughter. After a fantastic Sunday brunch at Rose Cafe, we strolled down Abbot Kinney and popped into whatever store caught our fancy. We loved that there is such a mix of places... homegoods, clothing, food... and a mix of prices from high-end to thrifty. Capped it all off with a delicious ice cream at Salt & Straw. Can't wait to go back another time!

An eclectic group opt restaurants and stores that are fun to explore and super food to discover. Lots of people to watch and meet and lots of places to hang out at during the day or night. One of my favourite streets in LA for sure.

a once funky artsy and great street about to totally gentrify. get there before all the chain stores do. good gift shops, restos clothing and coffee shops. it's a great girls afternoon out if u r looking for something different
... and hang out eating amazing donuts and browsing awesome stores along Abbot Kinney. I loved the mix of stores, interspersed with selfie ready street art back drops. This street has real character!
Great area for drinking and having fun at night in LA! Very safe and fun friendly. You will meet lots of good looking ppl too

Yes, this area more or less oozes pretention, but the upside of its upscale, pre-fab rusticity is it's a fun, safe place to window shop and people watch.Yes, the donuts are four bucks each. Yes, the vintage shoes cost $700 a pair. Yes, you can only buy a pair of jeans if you have $300 burning a hole in your pocket. (These are actual prices folks - not exaggerations.) Still, if browsing small boutiques run by snooty art school types doesn't intimidate you, there's plenty of cool stuff to see.Several blocks of fancy beach decor, cool street art and California-style casual couture await, along with umpteen high-end coffee houses and vegan, gluten-free everything. Trendsters will kick themselves if they miss it.

column2: Street full of interesting and funky shops
column3: It is indeed interesting to read about Abbot Kinney and his ingenious plan to create Venice of America in the late 1800s. What ambition and foresightedness. Most people have no idea that that is the real name of the city, they most often call it Venice Beach.There is much to see and enjoy on this street from galleries, shops and eateries. It is especially diverting to come during one of the Art Walks. No one is disappointed---except it is a long street and one might tire from the walk, and there is traffic as everyone wants to visit the area.

column2: #1 retail-restaurnant walking street in southern California
column3: Eponymous name to founder of Venice CA, the street morphed organically into one of most exciting few blocks in all of southern California
A gem of a street leading you into the best of Venice beach California. Food, shopping,anything you desire

Variety of restaurants for fun lunch. Strolling you will find a few interesting shops to browse. Street. Ot overly crowed unless it's during one of the fairs. When they have street fair fun but difficult to find parking.

So this street is now less of the vintage rumble sale and more of the home style front cover. Quite a few coffee shops, eclectic one off stores, clothes and dinnerware. Most of the regenerated section at the Venice Beach end, and runs out about 3/4 of the way up.Worth a look, and popular Lemonade is nearer the far end.
If you want to check out a really hip street in Venice with lots of restaurants and stores this is the place to go.

column2: Nice street of shops and restaurants
column3: We strolled down here during the evening after walking around on the boardwalk. Interesting collection of shops, some local and some chains; along with restaurants.
This is a great place for shopping and eating, it's a nice stroll too, the shops are mainly high end so you can easily spend some serious money while you are there...really nice though
really good place to be for a laid back look of the area. very eclectic mix of individuals and shops as well as restaurants. if you happen to be in the area, its worth stopping by.

column2: Nice to spend a few hours walking and looking at the various boutiques. Good restaurants as well.
column3: Good way to start a weekend. Have breakfast at any of the in place nearby and the walk it off on Abbott Kinney blvd. The boutiques are all so interesting. Definitely worth the time . You see the most interesting things and people.
Walk down this funky street and see what the competition to the big box stores look like. Priced high, much if the goods are made and designed in the USA which is quite refreshing. Worth a detour.
Charming stores and enormous variety of eating establishments. Fun place to walk and browse. When going to Venice Beach, this is a wonderful addition to the experience.

My best friend and I were on a girls trip and thought we would ride our bikes down to check out the hippest street in the U.S.Been there done that and have no need to return. We found it to be a place to be seen with over priced shops with pretentious people walking around.
Been a couple of times during my visit to Venice. There are plenty of good vegetarian restaurants and nice design shops.

After spending almost half a day in Venice, a friend suggested we walk a few blocks to AK and try to choose a place where we can have dinner. Walking the entire stretch both sides of the street was quite entertaining. Judging from the establishments and its patrons, one can surmise that it's a bit on the high-end side as compared to Venice. The neighborhood is actually nice. There is a wide variety of restaurants and bars to choose from- all hip and trendy. A haven for millennials and hipsters. This is one place I wouldn't mind hanging out every once in a while if only for the experience... and because I love to people watch. We finally ended up in a place called GreenGrocer but that's another review.

I wanted to stop by the Toms store being a huge fan of their shoes and just see what it was like. I did not belong. Honestly it was neat walking through but unless you are a huge hipster and have money to blow at the expensive boutique's it isn't worth the visit.

column2: Salt Air Restaurant on Abbott Kinney Blvd in Venice, CA
column3: Our family spent a week experiencing Venice Beach and finding this street with all it has to offer provided a special view of old and new Venice. Salt Air was our favorite Seafood restaurant on this strip and I highly recommend their Oysters! Service, ambiance, food, and the trendy people made for a special evening.

As soon as your getting on Abbot, You feel the Venice spirit... The Art is everywhere... On the walls, on the streets, in the shops and in the restaurants... You'll find it all... If you go don't miss lunch at Kreation and end your diner at Djelina's with the butterscotch!!! Orgasmic!!!!

Walk slow, be curious and enjoy a Boulevard loaded with small shops and the greatest atmosphere. You must try the homemade Salt and Straws ice-cream and the acai bowl at Another Kind of Sunrise... and go eat at the Butchers Daughter. Your coffee has to be from Blue Bottle or Intellegencia.... ENJOY :)
this is a trendy, boutique-y restaurant and clothing store street. combine with a trip to venice beach.

column2: Good vibes, friendly people, gorgeous shops and cafés
column3: I booked a bungalow on adjacent Palms Boulevard and discovered Abbot Kinney by chance. What a fab street to hang around. Less than a mile away from the crazy and fab - in another way - Venice Boardwalk, the Abbot Kinney Boulevard is a little jewel in LA.Lingered with little boutique and shops, cool restaurants and bars you will find there unusual boho chic stuff to buy. I nearly wanted to buy in every shop, but budget halas has its limits.Abbot Kinney is like a village, the kind of place you want to come back to again and again because you feel warmely welcomed.

Live nearby and have watched this area change a lot! The stores are creative and eclectic. Really the "Soho" of LA. Big money has driven out some of the small favorites that us locals loved....but the feeling is still very special and unique. Come here often.
It's a must while it lasts. It's changing rapidly, being taken over by little chain stores and restaurants, so enjoy it now while still has some unique boutiques and great restaurants

We were pleasantly surprised with the quality and style of the clothing and that it was reasonably priced! Don't go if you are looking for Walmart or discount shopping. These are designer and high end duds but the service was fabulous and there was a plethora of shops and styles to choose from! A good 2-3 hours just to peruse the 6 blocks or so. Great ice cream shoppes and restaurants as well!

column2: Super Fun and Great Walking in Venice
column3: Abbot Kinney Blvd. is about 9 blocks of walking, maybe a tad more. Parking is on the street and you will find something but mind the signs so you are not ticketed.It is a super fun street. There are cool little shops with new items, vintage and antique. There is something for everyone.There are several real great places to eat, be it a sandwich, just coffee or fine dinning, it is all there.Abbot was always a cool little street. In the 60's there were a couple of bars (one is still there) and some antique shops scattered among a few small homes. The area went down and then in the 80's starting to rise again with more shops and fairs during the summer when the street would be closed.It is now a wonderful place to visit. It is some of the best of Venice. Tourists are welcome and the locals are uber friendly and can direct you to food or drink. There is a great Gay bar there and it is okay for you to go, Gay or otherwise.You can sit outside of a few little places and have coffee and a muffin or lunch.You can spend the whole day there. You can walk to the beach from there but it is a quite a walk, I would not.Have a great time.

I've seen the transformation of Abbot Kinney. I loved it back when it was dirty-cool and I still love it now that it has cool galleries, shops and restaurants lining it.It is great for people watching. TONS of very good restaurants and bars. You can easily spend an afternoon here.

column2: Glad I stumbled across this Blvd
column3: Asking quite a few people for recommendations, I don't know why nobody recommended here. Has a great feel, Blue Bottle coffee (which is why I came, little did I know it was somewhat of a shopping boulevard), lots of places to eat and quite a few (expensive) shops. Nice atmosphere here.

Abbot Kinney Blvd is an absolute must visit, it reminds you of why so many people moved to SoCal, it's teaming with funky shops and restaurants, it has a Bohemian feel to it and the locals are great to chat with. You can literally spend the entire day wandering up and down the Boulevard and still miss a shop or two. Once you run out of steam there are a plethora of watering holes to take advantage of. Enjoyed the entire time.
Abbott Kinney Blvd has a nice, diverse selection of restaurants and shops. Parking was relatively easy for the area. And there was a nice selection of ice cream shops!

column2: Great upscale, away from the riff raft of the beaches place.
column3: Get off of the beach and up here for a little more class and neat shopping. Nice cafes also. Great place to walk and shop some unique stores.
Great area if you want to do feed all your senses. Walking distance to the beach and close to all those picture perfect bungalows!

Although most gravitate to the boardwalk, the boardwalk shops and food establishments are geared to tourists.Abbott Kinney, is more for the locals, with upscale shopping, and restaurants. This is the place to go to eat and shop for one off items, and boutique stores.

Charged us two times for a place we never stayed, including cleaning. Were rude. Alert! We booked through bookings.com, and cancelled within 24 hours. Contract said we "couldn't cancel free of charge." We tried to work it out, and they were horribly rude.

column2: Very busy and fun street to visit.
column3: Located in Venice, this street has many boutique stores,restaurants and hotels. Lots of interesting places to eat and a lot of people always walking in the neighborhood. Parking can be a problem, but you can always take Uber there. most restaurants don't take reservations, do be prepared to wait.

column2: The off the beach shopping street in Venice Beach
column3: Original ( not chain) shopping stores and interesting food establishments. Much better than the actual beach front area , which is sleazy.

column2: An eclectic street full of people watching, great shopping and great foid
column3: Abbott Kinney Boulevard is the place to go for an eclectic street ambiance full of a unique selection of artsy people, rather expensive and luxurious shopping and some really great dining experiences. People watching is unique and very colorful although the main dress color is black-sometimes with purple hair.Some street artwork is poetic, inspiring or far out. I love this area for its creative energy and artistic vibe. This area of Venice Beach offers great entertainment during the day, but avoid walking off the street at night. The seemingly peaceful neighborhood behind Abbott Kinney changes when it gets dark and can become dangerous at night.
We strolled along this lovely street after a wonderful lunch at Gjelina. There are cute little shops, restaurants and a wonderful vibe. Many people around. Definitely worth a visit.

column2: A lovely street to wander down
column3: This street is great, packed with restaurants, shops and galleries. You can easily while away a couple of hours wandering round at a relaxed pace.
We went here yesterdayAfter checking out the canals. It is a cute street with shopping and restaurants. I love the murals! It has a wonderfulVibe, a great place to people watch.

column2: Head Over Heels In Love with This Spot!
column3: One stroll down Abbot Kinney and I was sold. I was ready to leave everything behind to live in one of the hip houses that lines this street. You have fantastic food spots (like Lemonade) and chic boutiques. We were there during a festival and the place was swarming with hipsters, food trucks and yogi masters. Everyone that we encountered was super laid back. I could spend hours walking around here.

column2: Walking, dining and shopping...all the while people watching
column3: Iconic stretch of shopping and dining in Venice.Used to be eclectic and funky and is now sorta yuppie shopping and pseudo foodie restaurants. Kinda like Melrose in Hollyweird.Good people watching: locals and touristsStarts on the west end at the now closed Joes and ends east at lemonadeRelentless traffic-parking enforcement! Watch the signs.

A delight to walk on this street, the selection suits those who have passed the stage of shopping among the large chains. Boutques like Heist and Huset makes it particularly privileged to visit. Full of juice bars, cafes and really good restaurants.

You can do everything' at Abbot Kinney Blvd. there are boutiques all over with different styles of clothes. There are restaurants and cafes. Very charming, eclectic, and cool. There are vinyls for sale, shoes, antiques, you name it. Only down side is trying to find a parking spot.

If you want a a wide variety of shops - from Herbs to Hats, from Sushi to Lemonade - this is your spot. Shop high end designer or go hang out in the Mystic Journey bookshop for a REAL hit of LA. Totally charming, eclectic and fun.

Forget the tardy reputation of Venice Beach. This street is cool. Clothes, coffee shops, laid back trendoids, high street experience. Not that long so you can walk up and down in an hour or two. Kind off a redemption of the 'poser' LA vibe to be found eslsewhere.

column2: Great place to take it easy..
column3: From funky shops to hipster coffee shop this is a great place to hang out and buy things you don't necessarily need but definitely want!

column2: Great shopping street with funk and style
column3: I've never wandered around here before, so when my son, who attends college nearby, said, Lets go, I didn't complain. Something for everyone. There's a Happy Sock store here, one of only two such in the country. Dynamite sock selection of rad patterns, themes, and quality. Lots of small emporiums that were unique to the street. Parfumeries, leather goods, bakeries, restaurants, cafes, art, clothing - all the likes of which are here in a critical mass. Worth a couple of hours browsing time!! Go.
Good place to spend a sunny day walking around looking at shops. Lots of small places to eat. Parking may be tricky but getting there earlier in the day can help.

This street is lined with an incredible assortment of shops, restaurants and other services. Some shops are high end and very chic, while others are very bohemian and within reach of the average shopper. The restaurants run the gamut of world, organic and sustainable cuisine. The only drawback of the street is its conspicuous lack of parking. Don't even try finding a spot on the weekends.
If you want a charming stroll to explore local shops, hip top restaurants and a street scene, this is the place. A great antidote to shopping malls and the large name stores.
It's an amazing place. You can shop unique boutiques and eat at several farm to table spots. There's lots of culture to absorb and plenty of bars for a fun filled night life.
If you like to eat, you have a lot to pick from on what has become the restaurant row of Venice. Plenty of art shops and clothing choices as well.

column2: Quirky area of shops and restaurants
column3: Located in an area adjacent to Venice and Marina del Rey, Abbot Kinney Boulevard offers an interesting selection of places for lunch or dinner and some unique shops.

What a find parallel to one end of main street. terrific artisan shops and bars, various eateries for everyone and everybody and I mean everybody is super friendly. Classic cars and ice cream as well as designer clothes and fine dining. If you like drinking coffee in-between strolling around for the day this is the place for you. TIP- take valet public parking for $6, its worth it, parking fines are zero tolerance and $65, trust me i know
Wonderful day or night. Great restaurants and shops. Something for everyone. Close to the beach too.

It's not a normal street & not what you'd expect to find in LA - in San Francisco maybe? But Abott Kinney is LA / Venice at its eclectic best. Unusual shops & boutiques, clothiers, cafes, restaurants and street art which befits the area. It's pretty cool!, ...

Funky Street With Extraordinarily ShopsSuper cool, funky, extraordinarily, fashionable, vintage and yummy street.You can find cool vintage and high fashion stores mixed up with flower, furniture, interior, design stores.Amazing little restaurants, caffee.

column2: If You're in La, Do Not Miss This!!!
column3: Named the coolest street by GQ. Surely there isn't another street like this in the US. The definition of unique. No chains. Super cool. Super hip. Be sure to check out the Toms store's coffee shop. We went Fri night during First Fridays festival. There were many food trucks. I do not know if that is the norm. We mostly window shopped. It was neat to experience something so different and authentic. If you have time for only one shopping experience do this!

column2: Best place to shop in when in LA
column3: Abbott Kinney is a four block stretch of eclectic and bohemian shops and restaurants. If you don't mind stepping into phone sized stores, then you will really get into the vibe of this part of LA.Abbott Kinney is a collection of old houses and stores retrofitted into shopping and dining. My favorite shop has been Zingara, which is a women's and children' fashion shop. Great vintage dresses for the bride and daughter. I love buying their woolen products for family Xmas gifts. Another new favorite is Happy Socks. They sell crazy socks which make my day a little happier.They have high end fashion items in these stretch of stores. Parking is extremely limited. I recommend going during the day as the place really packs out at night.

The restaurants, cafes that dot abbot kinney are all good choices. Sometimes they have food trucks, too, and you can sample yummy food at reasonable prices. There are a lot of stores that carry unique items (no massive chain here), definitely a neat little street to explore.
This is a vibrant retail area. It is a lot of fun with unique stores, everything from ice cream to home furnishings to books to fashion. A fun area to walk around

A sort of reverse Rodeo Drive with "cool boutiques" selling overpriced clothes, overall this feels like a laboured and ultimately futile attempt at being hip. An interesting way to spend an hour or so but real shopping can be done at far more reasonable cost elsewhere.

The boulevard has become a very ritzy neighborhood that is so pricey, even dot-com millionaires grit their teeth over the prices. Lots of trendy restaurants and unique shops. An interesting area to stroll and graze.

Abbot Kinney Blvd is just a short street full of hip, trendy, and cute shops and restaurants. Lots of cool street art, too!We're staying in an AirBnB nearby, and Abbot Kinney has been our go-to spot for drinks, dinner, and shopping. Everyone is very nice and laid back, and we've yet to meet any jerky people there. This area is well worth a visit if you're in the area. Much cooler than he Boardwalk in my opinion!
If you are somewhat tired by malls and all-show-the-same chain stores, this is the place to go to. Took friends from Germany yesterday, and they loved it - MUCH more than Venice Beach by the way.

column2: Unique shops and great looking cafes
column3: Even though Abbot Kinney Boulevard is within striking distance of Venice Beach and its boardwalk, this shopping and eating street is a world away in terms of food and shopping offerings - and most particularity, atmosphere. There is a large range (apart of hipster men walking little dogs) of unique clothes shops (not cheap) and very nice independent cafes and restaurants. I felt really comfortable wandering the shops along either side of the boulevard. Not everything is outrageously priced - I got a very nice unique fox print shirt for $99 and I'm 100% certain I won't see it anywhere else in the world. We walked here from Santa Monica along the beach boardwalk and it took 45 minutes.
great for window shopping, shopping, strolling, eating at fine restaurants, with easy access to Venice Beach.
Nice place to have breakfast and then walk around, do some shopping or something else. There are nice stores, beauty salons and beautiful people.

column2: Cool place to spend an afternoon
column3: Great shops and restaurants and people watching along the boulevard in venice. Good mix of high end shops with some unique ones and some moderately prices ones.

column2: great for a day of shopping and eating!
column3: so much fun to wander on abbott kinney- great shops and cafes and fine dining. fantastic way to spend a day in LA.

column2: Tough Parking and pricey but very cool
column3: AK has a vibe all its own. For example, you can spot the local men by the a) beard b) man bun and/or porkpie hat and c) small dog. Essentially, AK is a shopping/eating zone with Venice/SoCal flair. What's great is that for the most part there are no chain stores, it's mostly unique, eclectic shops. Like, the restaurants and coffee bars are great; it's hard to go wrong with almost any choice. My advice is that if you have the time do half of AK one day and the other half another day so it's more relaxed and you can have a great meal as a break. Lastly, do bring your credit cards. AK is definitely not a budget visit.

We weren't having a great impression of LA at first but a waitor recommended this area for us to visit. We loved it!Love the graffiti. lots of trendy cute little shops and eateries.You can just park on the side road for free.Must go!

We had brunch at a little place on Abbot Kinney Boulevard. Afterwards, we walked along the sidewalks, taking in the shops, beautiful gardens with huge succulents and some interesting art. One wall along the way was a woman's face. The wall...part brick, part cement....was chiseled away to leave a face. Very cool!! We were walking before some of the shops opened, but it's a great little boulevard and a nice stroll.

The highlight of our LA stay. Abbott Kinney and Venice canals/Venice beach beat all other L.A. attractions hands down.Lots of artsy shops, cosy bars and restaurants. We should have spent our entire time on this street alone. Go, you won’t be disappointed!

We were pleasantly surprised with the cool, one off shops of Abbot Kinney in Venice Beach. The famous boardwalk and this boulevard have nothing in common and that is a good thing! Lots of interesting boutiques and small brunch type cafes populate this gentrifying section of Venice Beach. Well worth a visit!

I loved Abbot Kinney, very much appreciated the alternative shopping area/eateries being in my mid-twenties. All locals and rare to see a tourist here which was a breath of fresh air. Cute boutiques and quirky shops. Much appreciated by a Londoner, would love to go back.

The area was great and had lots of interesting shops and people. I'd go again.Being from the east coast where the general population has a consistent work schedule, it was certainly interesting to run into a conversation between a customer and a shopkeeper who seemed to be friends. When the shopkeeper asked 'what have you been up to this am?', the friend replied 'I'm so exhausted! I had to get up early today...around 9:30 to get to a meeting and it was a long meeting... I had a very busy, exhausting morning.'I couldn't help but laugh because it was noon. Wow. People don't work in LA.

A boy Kinney is a great street for an afternoon stroll. There are so many awesome restaurant options. Start out with lunch at Lemonade or Chop Daddy's. The window shop at some of the high end boutiques. Hit up Burro for great knick knacks, coffee table books, and jewelry. And of course grab a scoop of gelato.If you are around in the evening there are some bars and trendy restaurants worth a try. Zinque and Salt Air are favorites. And make sure to try Primitivo for happy hour!

Abbott Kinney is quite a long street with unique stores selling California-styled, upscale clothes. Give yourself a few hours to walk both sides of the street (take car j walking as it's very busy!) taking in the small shops and vendors. There are quite a few cafes serving healthy food and coffee.

There are a lot of unique shops here. I would recommend a walk as the weather is awesome and there is a lot to see. However, most shops were really expensive. As an example, my daughter found some cute short-shorts. At a normal store I'd said they should cost $30- $50 since they were unique and of high quality. That said, they were $145. For shorts! I would say 90% of the stores we visited were just as expensive if not more so. If you're high roller, spend away but for the middle class, have fun but save your pennies.

column2: Cool local vibe-great food and shopping.
column3: Whenever I am in town, I go check out the Abbot Kinney shops kand enjoy some great eats and coffee. Check out the locals only vibe, cool stores selling fun fashions, home apparel. Enjoy a coffee in the inner courtyard of the Tom's shop, enjoy free wifi, check out the shades and cool new kicks. Unique gifts can be found in many of the stores. Go. It's easy to find free parking.

column2: Convenient, delicious, fun and appeals to your I'm-shopping-on-holiday desires...definitely...
column3: Abbott Kinney is filled with coffees with extended biographies, pastries with gluten and without, and those carelessly chic accessories that are occasionally eyebrow-raising, but when on vacation seem suddenly not that unreasonable. Zinque (Abott K and Venice Boulevard) was a favorite of ours- good wines, nice breakfasts. Everyone was fun, friendly around these parts, absolutely. Don't miss the weekend markets with cute accessories, get travel tips from the chatty and sweet vendors and enjoy! Park behind Abott Kinney on one of those side streets- saves a penny or two.
Worth a visit ,excellent food and boutiques ,lots of tourists but also cool young localsvalet parking is easy and it is close to Santa Monica

While the rest of the tourists are in Santa Monica and Venice beach, the high end, cool, hipsters are shopping on abbot Kinney. This street goes a couple of blocks and the shops on it are just great.A number of art galleries, clothing, and really cool odd and ends.I almost don't want to ruin this great little area by giving its beauty away to tourists .Just two streets over is Venice beach and the boardwalk which has a much more grimy and dirty feel, which is opposite of Abbot Kinney.Check out the great street art in all the alleys!

column2: Boho Vibe - nice for a stroll
column3: Abbot Kinney has a unique feel to it that the rest of LA does not. Lots of boho boutique shops and restaurants - it's well worth a stroll

A great collection of unique, non-chain, shops with everything from interesting things for your garden to nice clothing. Numerous Restaurents made selecting a location for lunch easy. Also within walking distance of the Venice Canals and Venice Beach.
Abbott Kinney is a great place for strolling, shopping, window shopping, getting one's hair done, breakfasting, brunching, lunching, munching, noshing, eating, dining.... even for non-hipsters!

column2: Tortoise General Store...T H E B O M B !!!!!
column3: 1208 abb0tt kinneyOkay, Trip Advisor will not allow me to highlight individual stores that are not in the categories they provide (let me know if I am wrong) so I need to work around the system a bit.Tortoise is the absolute bomb when it comes to housewares and gifts (for others and yourself!). All items are from Japan. Don't forget to visit their house in the back for more select items and exhibitions. Plan on spending and count on regretting nothing! E N J O Y ! ! ! ! ! !

A friend from L.A. gave me the idea to visit Abbot Kinney Boulevard in Venice, CA. It's a fun place with an abundance of little shops and amazing creative places. Also for eating out, this is a great place. And for a good strong coffee, don't miss Intelligentsia Venise Coffee bar.Worth visiting.

column2: Nice street with lots of interesting shops and restaurants
column3: If you are a foody this is a place to visit. Lots of restaurant/bars and shops, nice new concepts and always full of people. Nice mix of old and new and just 10 min from Santa Monica.
What a refreshing and diverse choice of eclectic boutiques, shops and restaurants, totallly laid back. No single chain outlet, Great for a morning brunch, an afternoon stroll or a night walk.

Great restaurants here, but reservations required. Boutiques, clothes and jewelry, hair salons, specialty shops, and again, a lot of great restaurants - all down one strip of road 4 blocks long. Kreations has fresh pressed juice selection to keep you rolling.

As a lot of other reviewers mention, this is a 'hipster' street, with lots of great boutique shops and restaurants for teenagers through to people in their 30's/40's.I personally loved it and so did my partner and we spent hours weaving into and out of shops as well as the cafes and bars. The atmosphere is nice and the shops are great and original, it was finally what I had expected LA to be.
I wasn't impressed, but my 15 and 21 year old daughters LOVED it! Very close to Venice Beach which is a lot of fun to walk and souvenir shop.

column2: Great for walking and window shopping (and eating)
column3: Less than a mile from the ocean is a single street filled with expensive clothing shops, increasingly popular and delicious (but not inexpensive) restaurants and a growing number of coffee and juice shops. What's the big draw then - hip, cool people-watching, occasional celeb sighting, all dressed to impress in whatever is trending at the moment. If you can't get a table at any of the places on Abbot Kinney then you can wander over to nearby, up and coming Rose Ave where the restaurants aren's as crowded.On the weekends there are plenty of people wandering around with kids in strollers and toddlers - but there really isn't anything for kids to do on this street (except the ice cream shop).

column2: Nice to walk through, but not to shop
column3: I personally think the place is a little overrated but I had to go there because my girlfriend wanted to.Tons of hipsters on that street and the shops and boutiques are basically made for that group of people.The stores have some pretty interesting stuff to sell but most are completely overprized.We did have fun just walking around and looking at stuff but i probably won't go there again because it's just not my kind of spot to shop or hang out

Good grief - this is one of those places where I felt under-dressed just to walk down the street. There are a few places that are not crazy-expensive. We REALLY enjoyed "Tortoise General Store" which has incredible USEFUL products displayed in a museum-like space. It was the coolest place. Tom's has a "roastery" or some such thing, a very L.A. type place with people just hanging out on their laptops drinking their coffee drinks out on the back deck. We also enjoyed Sunya Currie which had reasonably priced gift items - scarves, jewelry, clothing, books, and very pleasant staff. There were other places with $700 pairs of shoes, and $300 scarves - WAYYYY over my budget, but fun, I guess, to browse.We found parking on the street at about 4:00, not sure how amazing that was, but maybe amazing for a tourist town.
Not a family friendly area. Overpriced boutiques and rude foreign tourists and locals. Some interesting architecture but that's it.

column2: Not to miss if your in this area
column3: We walked from Santa Monica along the beach boulevard. It took about 30 minutes. It's a beautiful walk. Cute shops and adorable architecture. Great shopping for clothing! The stores are pricey but unique items. I loved the jewellery kiosks. Beautiful original stuff for a great price.

column2: What a great place to visit in the evening hours!
column3: I visited on the first Friday of the month looking for some shopping and grab a bit to eat. Boy was I surprised to find a bunch of food trucks everywhere! It turns out, the first Friday of the month is Food Truck Friday!! I nibbled my way up and won the blvd. I even tried some famous food trucks that were featured on the Food Network! What a treat! Besides the food indulgences, there were also lots of cute boutiques. No chain stores, just charming boutiques offering uniqueness. If you don't want food trucks, I cant imagine why, there are also lots of restaurants to choose from. I would suggest making reservations because in some places the line was out the door. Street parking could be an issue unless you get there early. I arrived around 4pm so I didn't have a problem. I also parked strategically so I minimized unnecessary walking. Not sure if there was paid parking available since I found free parking. I would recommend getting there earlier if you want to shop since most of the stores closed around 6-7pm. The food trucks were opening around 6pm. The restaurants were opened when I arrived around 4pm. So I would recommend, grab some truck grub, get something to drink, grab more grub, then have dinner in one of the restaurants! After all, it was a Friday nite!

Had a good time strolling along the boulevard and stopping at the local art shops and boutiques along the way. If you like natural stones in jewelry, you have to check out Made in Earth, which was my favorite store. No chain stores on this street. We visited on a Thursday morning and had no problem finding a parking spot along the street, which was free 2 hour parking.

column2: Take a stroll down a unique street
column3: All the stores and restaurants along this strip are appealing for browsing and taking time to drink in the atmosphere. the shops aren't any of the chain store names you find in malls, but are unique with artsy crafts items that will allow you to find something unique for a gift or yourself

Loved everything about it! My adrenaline started pumping the minute we turned onto the street and there was a lineup of shops as far as the eye could see! lol. We had GPS'd the location, and parked at one end so we could work our way down the street. Unfortunately, it was our last day in town and it was a Sunday, so we didn't have enough time to REALLY canvas the area like we wanted to... but from the shops we DID hit... we were in heaven! LOVED LOVED LOVED it and can't wait to go back! We normally stay in West Hollywood when we visit the LA area, but I think I'm going to try the Santa Monica/Venice area next time for something a little different. There are SO many fun places to shop and eat... all with a little taste of local flavor... love the offbeat designers and casual atmosphere. I DID think some of the goods were a bit overpriced (and I'm not normally one to complain about price)... probably thinking they could justify it because of location?! I've seen similar items on etsy for FAR cheaper! Some designers though... their prices were well justified... and I just LOVED the boutiques!!! OH, and definitely opt to park in a paid parking lot w/an attendant (and don't leave purchase bags or luggage in your car!)... better safe than sorry... there are a LOT of "interesting" people wandering around ;)

Honestly, I didn't see the appeal. I imagined a street with more fun shops. We didn't try a restaurant. We walked the street, both sides, stopped into a couple of blahhh shops, and were done in half an hour. Not for us.

Abbot Kinney has a lot of local flavor with art, local designers, lots of good food, interesting shops. Robert Downey Jr. owns a home on this street and I doubt when people walk past that they even know it's his home since the old homes on the street have all been turned into shops or offices, his place is more modern so I think most see it as an office space. It's a good spot for good food and a walk after.

Snazzy up & happened area. You may want to flex your AM EX or window shop. I opted for the latter! High end independent boutiques, modern architecture butts up against old style beach cottages, funky cafes & achingly trendy design & 'concept' stores. All this makes for a fascinating walk down "lifestyle' avenue. The hippies have left the house, the yuppies are thriving & the brands are stealthily marching in. A sign of the times?
It's very nice street with some nice boutique shops on, some very overpriced! Definitely for the wealthy!Overall very nice and well worth a look at.
no chain stores, very bohemian retail choices, GREAT restaurants, good people watching, some movie star sightings (they live in the hood) excellent for gift buying

If you don't want to see chain stores or hear mall Muzak -- like almost all retail venues in L.A. -- then this is your place. Lots of funky little shops (not cheap) and good bars and restaurants. if you want to see how the legal medical marijuana market works in CA, walk into The Farmacy. You can't buy, but you can look.
Great shops for window shopping and finding that special thing. Lots and lots of fantastic eateries. We had brunch at Joe's which was excellent.

column2: Shops are neat but way too expensive!
column3: The shops were nice and some were privately owned while others were chain stores. I found the shops to be very expensive and my kids and family were bored. It did have a community vibe and people were friendly. One review stated there were several food trucks. We only saw two. That was the highlight for the kids as they each ordered a special hotdog from the hotdog truck. There was also a very nice farmer's market a few miles away that we enjoyed.

Venice Beach is depressing. Santa Monica is touristy. Rodeo Drive is chi-chi. Abbott Kinney Boulevard is a stretch of independent, unique shops. Jewelry, vintage clothing, one-of-a-kind pieces all along one very walkable boulevard. Try the lemonade, have a stroll, and spend some time here.
Park the car and walk around the entire area here. Slip into a gallery or two, taste some wine and have lunch or dinner. A nice area to spend a day shopping and tasting.
There are so many good restaurants here, and I do my Christmas shopping on this street for those individuals in my life that I REALLY love.Loved by tourists and locals alike
Interesting, unique stores. Some of the best people watching in LA. Try the Tasting Kitchen restaurant.
WOW this was fun. Wandered all the stores and all the food trucks were out. Even cupcake truck. It was really the artistic district and fun for any tourist or native.

Far from the madding crowds of Venice Beach is this great little shopping street with cool cafes, restaurants, bars, clothes shops and hairdressers. GTA is a particular highlight for me, with awesome pizza and cake. The clothes shops are very cool = very expensive. There is an amazing pop up designer clothes store there at the moment and if you are under a size US 4 you will love it! Spend a couple of hours down there, then go walk round the canals.
Über hip southern california ecosystem of beach meets beautiful intellectuals meets disposable incomes.

column2: Best shopping street in Los Angeles
column3: This would be the best shopping street in Los Angeles.If your looking for a European bohemian worldly atmosphere (stores carrying the likes of Isabel Marant, Vanessa Bruno etc). The shopping, delicious food, G'linas a must & great people watching a little piece of downtown New York in LA. Newly opened boutique Flannel a highlight. Just read was voted by GQ best strip in America. Enjoy. I did!

column2: Fun way to spend the day
column3: Abbott Kinney has really changed in the last few years, with more small vintage shops, art galleries, and one-of-a-kind boutiques. It is a perfect place to find unusual gifts, or eclectic and artsy accessories for your home. It is fun to wander back and forth, and stop for lunch at one of the many wonderful restaurants along the way. The quality of the food has really arrived, with farmer's market produce and young and talented chefs. My favorites are Gjelina, Tasting Kitchen, and also, Joe's at the other end of the block. Parking sometimes can be a little tough, depending on time of day, but there are a few lots around.

This is no ordinary LA street. Like many shopping areas it offers a collection of designer shops, cafes, local shops and residencies. But it is all do-able on foot. The big feature is that it is incredibly creative from the architecture, the contents in the shops and the people. This is not just my favourite place in LA, but possibly the world.
This area is full of quirky shops, boutiques, vintage surf clothes like Aviator Nation, and a number of cute gift shops. Very chic, very trendy, and full of character. Definitely worth taking a peek

Interesting shops and good restaurants along the blvd.Had lunch at the French Cafe and Market, and sat on the outside deck with friends and our dog. If you are looking for hard to find French food products, this is the place.Overall, spent and enjoyable day walking along the street.

column2: A fun, hip destination for shopping and eating
column3: So much of LA is spread out across so many different areas,its always a relief to find a pocket of food, fashion, and general flair where you can actually wander up and down sidewalks for more than a few blocks in a row. Abbott Kinney has such a unique silhouette...low, one-story buildings, none of the glitz of Beverly Hills or even Santa Monica, but the restaurants and shops are a really exciting mix, not a dud in the bunch. The culture is young but not off-putting for anyone over 40, and a couple of the stores are truly exceptional - worth the drive from whatever part of the city you're in. Most tourists don't discover this little gem, preferring to stay in the more "known" areas, so it's very insider-ish in feeling, like Soho in the early 80's. I always make sure to cruise over there whenever I'm in LA - and during the week, street parking is generally easy to find.
So many unique and interesting shops and great places to eat. Plus they have fun first friday with great food trucks.
Its a happening gentrified area-lots of interesting shops and restaurants

Abbot Kinney is the best place in Venice Beach. Keep away from the madness of out of towners checking the scene on the boardwalk. This 1 mile stretch of boutique shops,art, trendy restaurants, and bars is a fun place to spend the day with the family! Lots to do and see. Street Parking and if you like Valet is offered in some places. The boulevard comes alive at night with music and bars, and what a beautiful scene. Leave the babies at home. Every first Friday of the month the shops open late and a parade of gourmet food trucks park and serve up feast like truffle potatoes on a stick, BBQ, Mexican Food, Greek Food, etc. COME HUNGRY!

column2: "Hippest " street on the west side, to walk , dine and drink.
column3: Many options, for shopping, dining and people watching. Go to Gjelena for the best over all food, Hal's for bar and food, Princeppsa for women's shopping and the Mystic Journey bookstore, for readings, candles and of course books!
Love this street! Diverse, funky, stylish and tasty. Great hip young crowd, lots to see and try. One of my favorite places in LA.

Abbot Kinney Blvd in Venice Beach is just a perfect example of the boho chic lifestyle Venice and Los Angeles provides. It has a vast array of shops, dining, and culture, all of which are excellent experiences.
